results.title: Game Masters: Tetsuya Mizuguchi interview
results.creator_credit: Jim Arneman, ACMI Media Studio, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Tetsuya Mizuguchi started in the industry working for SEGA developing arcade games such as ‘Sega Rally’. In 1994 he was inspired by the street parades in Zurich and soon turned his love of synaesthesia, combining sound and vision, to produce the games ‘Rez’ and ‘Space Channel 5’. Mizuguchi continues to incorporate a notable emphasis on interactive sound design, with his latest game ‘Child of Eden’.

Currently he is co-founder of the videogame development firm Q Entertainment. NB: Interviewer is neither seen nor heard onscreen.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jim Arneman, ACMI Media Studio, ACMI Content Development and ACMI

results.title: Game Masters: Yuji Naka interview
results.creator_credit: Mike Kenneally, ACMI Media Studio, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Yuji Naka is a videogame designer and programmer, best known as the former head of Sonic Team, where he was the lead programmer of the original ‘Sonic the Hedgehog’. Naka reveals his initial desire to make arcade games and the influence that Yu Suzuki has had on his career as a programmer. Since 2006 he has been the head of Prope, an independent game company he founded after leaving SEGA.
Yuji gives great insights into the development and creation of ‘Sonic the Hedgehog 1 and 2’, ‘Nights into Dreams’ and ‘Chu Chu Rocket’.
NB: This interview was conducted in Yuji Naka’s native language of Japanese and features English subtitles. Interviewer is neither seen nor heard onscreen.

results.title: Game Masters: Paulina Bozek interview
results.creator_credit: Jim Arneman, ACMI Media Studio, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description:
Paulina Bozek started her career at Ubisoft in Montreal, Canada, before moving to Sony as the Executive Producer of the ‘SingStar’ franchise for PlayStation. Currently she is CEO and co-founder at INENSUA, responsible for overseeing the creative direction and team management for the development of social games and applications. A self-confessed casual gamer, Paulina studied film and communication and has always been interested in pop culture and the combination of technology and entertainment. In this interview she discusses her preference for working on long term projects, as well as the importance of user feedback and engaging the audience early in the development process.

In this interview Paulina talks about ‘SingStar’, ‘Closet Swap’ and her new project ‘Super Fan’. NB: Interviewer is neither seen nor heard onscreen.

results.title: Game Masters: Peter Molyneux interview
results.creator_credit: Csilla Csongvay, ACMI Media Studio, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description:
In this interview, featured as part of the ‘Game Masters’ exhibition, Peter Molyneux speaks about his career as a videogame designer. While selling baked beans, a once in a life time opportunity presented itself and Molyneux took advantage of his good fortune. His first game, ‘Populous’, became a huge worldwide success, surprising everyone, including himself. In this interview Peter talks about his inspirations, his work practise and his never-ending fascination with the notion of morality and choice. Now, as Creative Director of Microsoft Game Studios, Molyneux is one of the best known names in the videogames industry. Making his mark as a games designer and programmer, he has been responsible for a string of bestselling games, including ‘Populous’, ‘Dungeon Keeper’, ‘Black and White’ and ‘Fable I, II and III’.

NB: Interviewer is neither seen nor heard onscreen.

results.title: Game Masters: Warren Spector interview
results.creator_credit: Dean Robb, ACMI Media Studio, ACMI Content Development and ACMI
results.brief_description:
In this interview, featured as part of the ‘Game Masters’ exhibition, Warren Spector speaks about his career as a videogame designer. Warren refers to his days of playing ‘Dungeons and Dragons’ and the influence this has had on him as a vidoegames designer. A great collector of board games and Disney memorabilia, Warren talks with great passion about the importance of archiving and making games a medium worth recognising.

Warren Spector is a master of role playing game design and has been influenced and inspired by films and literature, such as ‘Blade Runner’ and cyberpunk science fiction, he is best known for creating influential titles such as ‘Deus Ex’ and his most recent release, ‘Disney Epic Mickey’.

NB: Interviewer is neither seen nor heard onscreen.

results.title: Game Masters: Tim Schafer interview
results.creator_credit: Mike Kenneally, ACMI Content Development, ACMI Media Studio and ACMI
results.brief_description:
In this interview, featured as part of the Game Masters exhibition, Tim Schafer speaks about his career as a game designer, starting at LucasArts and then founding his own production company Double Fine Productions. Tim discusses his influences, drawn heavily from the cultural folk law of Mexico, the psychological study of dreams, his love of heavy metal music and the writing of Raymond Chandler and Kurt Vonnegut Jr. With the progression of emerging technology his game aesthetics and character development have evolved, cementing Tim Schafer and Double Fine Productions’ place in games history.

Tim talks about his inspirations and work practices in developing the following games: ‘Full Throttle’, ‘Grim Fandango’, ‘Psychonauts’ and ‘Brutal Legend’. NB: Interviewer is neither seen nor heard onscreen.

results.title: On the Line
results.creator_credit: David Greig, John Richardson, SBS-TV and Kestrel Films & Video (Australia)
results.brief_description: It’s a harsh, lonely life for the men, mostly European migrants, who work maintaining the railway around Redmont in north-west Western Australia. Labouring through searing heat over 426 kilometres of mountainous, desert region, these men talk candidly about their lives, providing psychological and social insight into what it is to be living in “isolation”.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Greig, John Richardson, SBS-TV and Kestrel Films & Video (Australia)

results.title: Ceremony
results.creator_credit: David Greig and Experimental Film and Television Fund
results.brief_description: Nearly completing his painting, the artist takes a walk outside, where his creativity manifests itself in the life around him. This experimental work captures the ritualistic spirituality of art and the art in the everyday. Paintings in the film are by Paul Mason.
results.creator_credit_for_label: David Greig and Experimental Film and Television Fund

results.title: Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls
results.creator_credit: Marlene Rubuntja and Sally M Nangala Mulda
results.brief_description:
First Peoples were forcibly moved from their lands into designated camps by European colonists from around 1880 onwards. As a result of the ongoing displacement of First Peoples, Amoonguna was established as a government reserve 21kms from Mparntwe (Alice Springs) in 1963. Known as town camps today, reserves like Amoonguna make up the Alice Springs Aboriginal housing associations. These town camps are home to many artists who are extremely proud of their communities. English is often the third language of Amoonguna residents with the major language groups being Arrernte (pronounced Arenda), Warlpiri and Pitjantjatjara.

Mparntwe is a place where government policy and intervention in First Peoples communities has distinct and obvious implications. The Australian media often portrays this part of the nation negatively, without showing the historical narratives at play or the strength, beauty and talent that comes from the Central Desert. At the cetnre of the exhibition Two Girls From Amoonguna, is the animated video work Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls, which reminds audiences that Mparntwe is filled with joy and laughter. From camping and travelling to town to finding bush tucker, this place is home.

Tangentyere Artists and Yarrenyty Arltere Artists are akin to community hubs. Not only are they gallery and commercial spaces, but they are also places for young ones to learn and spaces for important community discussions.

For Sally M Nangala Mulda (Arrernte and Southern Luritja) and Marlene Rubuntja (Arrernte and Western Arrarnta), their art centres reflect their artistic practices. The soft sculpture, sewing and bush dyeing seen in Marlene’s works are synonymous with Yarrenyty Arltere Artists. Tangentyere artists like Sally are renowned for figurative paintings, which are often autobiographical and depict scenes in and around Mparntwe. These centres provide culturally safe places for artists and community. With the success of both artists, they have become prominent figures in their communities and teach many young people within their kinship structure. Intergenerational knowledge sharing is integral to First Peoples’ ways of life – you can even hear the voices of the artists’ nieces and nephews in the animated work.

Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls was made in collaboration with Ludo Studio, the Emmy-award winning production company behind Bluey, Robbie Hood and The Strange Chores. It is the third ACMI + Artbank Commission.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Marlene Rubuntja and Sally M Nangala Mulda
results.description:
Life in the Central Desert can be challenging, but it can also be breathtakingly beautiful. Two Girls From Amoonguna tells the intertwined story of Sally M Nangala Mulda and Marlene Rubuntja, from their childhood years to now as two of Australia’s leading artists, through paintings, sculptures and a newly commissioned animated video.

The animation Arrkutja Tharra, Kunkga Kutjara, Two Girls was inspired by a conversation between Sally and Marlene, held on the steps of the Sydney Opera House, where they reminisced about their shared childhood at the Amoonguna settlement, outside of Mparntwe (Alice Springs), in the early 1960s. Figures from Marlene’s soft sculptures and Sally’s acrylic-on-linen paintings come to
life, depicting life as they know it to create a portrait of two friends and the communities that made them.

Arrkutja Tharra, Kungka Kutjara, Two Girls was made in collaboration with Ludo Studio, the Emmy-award winning production company behind Bluey, Robbie Hood and The Strange Chores. It is the third ACMI + Artbank Commission.

results.title: The Dark Current
results.credit_line:
Ian Potter Moving Image Commission
ACMI Collection
Courtesy the artist and Sullivan + Strumpf, Sydney
results.brief_description:
“The Dark Current has a specific shape to it, that reaches for the essence of a multi-generational experience. One that starts with my mother’s generation, through to mine and on to our children.” Angela Tiatia, 2023

The Dark Current was conceived as a “dream-like visual poem” in three parts that represent the past, present and future. The artwork opens with a striking close-up of a glamorous woman with a pearl in her eye, who is slowly engulfed by water. The artist considers this scene an allegory of the promise that lured her mother’s generation to migrate from the Pacific Islands to countries like New Zealand and Australia in the 1960s.

The middle section weaves together choreographed performances filmed in a production studio with footage of Pacific Island landscapes. It seeks to capture the dark and chaotic feeling of the current moment, as the climate emergency and rising sea levels wreak catastrophic damage across the Pacific Islands and global south.

The final scene is created with software more commonly used to develop videogames. This hyper realistic world is filled with towering ice monuments set atop colourful disco flooring and populated by a cast of performers dressed in pink. The artist describes this joyful vision of the future as “a space of cultural self-actualisation and celebration.”

The Dark Current reflects how we no longer think of the physical and the virtual as being separate spaces, while celebrating Tiatia’s connection to her family history and Sāmoan culture.

Angela Tiatia is a Sāmoan and Australian artist who lives and works in Sydney. She works primarily with moving image and performance to explore contemporary culture, in particular the relationships between representation, gender, neo-colonialism and the commodification of body and place. Tiatia’s work has been exhibited nationally and internationally, and her work is held in private and public collections including Museum of New Zealand Te Papa Tongarewa; Art Gallery of New South Wales, Sydney; Museum of Contemporary Art, Sydney; National Gallery of Victoria, Melbourne; and Queensland Art Gallery | Gallery of Modern Art, Brisbane.

constellations_primary.name: Pink subversions
constellations_primary.description: Pink dominates Angela Tiatia's The Dark Current. The artist describes this particular colour as “artificial”, “unapologetic” and “pulsating with feminine energy”. In Tiatia's Sāmoan heritage “there is a brashness in the use of colour. I really wanted to embody that.”
